title: 113_s1837
content: The "Equal Employment for All Act of 2013" prohibits the use of credit checks for employment purposes. The Fair Credit Reporting Act prohibits the use of consumer reports for employment purposes or adverse actions, with exceptions outlined in the legislation. The Fair Credit Reporting Act prohibits the use of consumer reports for employment purposes or adverse actions, with exceptions outlined in the legislation. The prohibition applies even if the consumer consents to the use of the report. Exceptions allow employers to use consumer reports in specific situations. The Fair Credit Reporting Act allows for exceptions to using consumer reports for employment purposes, such as when required by law or for national security clearance. These exceptions do not affect other disclosure and notification requirements outlined in the Act. Amendments to the Act include changes to section 603 regarding the use of consumer reports. Amendments to the Fair Credit Reporting Act include changes to section 604, such as inserting "604(h)(3)" and updating subsections (o) and (a) to include restrictions outlined in subsection 604(b). Amendments to the Fair Credit Reporting Act involve changes to various subsections, including redesignating subsections and updating references in different sections. Amendments to the Fair Credit Reporting Act include updating references in different sections such as changing "604(b)(4)(E)(i)" to "604(c)(4)(E)(i)" and "604(b)(4)(A)" to "604(c)(4)(A)".
